sp.speaker: Diana
sp.p: Nowe things falling out as they doe, you must leaue these fond fond affections, nature will haue it so, necessitie must.

sp.speaker: Gallathea
sp.p: I will neuer loue any but Phillida, her loue is engrauen in my hart, with her eyes.

sp.speaker: Phillida
sp.p: Nor I any but Gallathea, whose faith is imprinted in my thoughts by her words.

sp.speaker: Neptune
sp.p: An idle choyce, strange, and foolish, for one Virgine to doate on another, and to imagine a constant faith, where there can be no cause of affection. Howe like you this Venus?

sp.speaker: Venus
sp.p: I like well and allowe it, they shall both be possessed of their wishes, for neuer shall it be said that Nature or Fortune shall ouer-throwe Loue, and Fayth. Is your loues vnspotted, begunne with trueth, continued wyth constancie, and not to bee altered tyll death?

sp.speaker: Gallathea
sp.p: Die Gallathea if thy loue be not so.

sp.speaker: Phillida
sp.p:
Accursed bee thou Phillida if thy loue be
not so.

sp.speaker: Diana
sp.p: Suppose all this Venus, what then?

sp.speaker: Venus
sp.p: Then shall it be seene, that I can turne one of them to be a man, and that I will.

sp.speaker: Diana
sp.p: Is it possible?

sp.speaker: Venus
sp.p: What is to Loue or the Mistrisse of loue vnpossible? Was it not Venus that did the like to Iphis and Iauthes; howe say yee are ye agreed, one to bee a boy presently?

sp.speaker: Phillida
sp.p: I am content, so I may imbrace Gallathea.

sp.speaker: Gallathea
sp.p: I wish it, so I may enioy Phillida.

sp.speaker: Melleb.
sp.p: Soft Daughter, you must know whether I will haue you a Sonne.

sp.speaker: Tyterus
sp.p: Take mee with you Gallathea, I will keepe you as I begatte you, a Daughter.

sp.speaker: Melleb.
sp.p: Tyterus, let yours be a boy and if you will, mine shall not.

sp.speaker: Tyterus
sp.p: Nay mine shall not, for by that meanes my young sonne shall lose his inheritance.

sp.speaker: Melleb.
sp.p: Why then gette him to be made a Maiden and then there is nothing lost.

sp.speaker: Tyte.
sp.p: If there bee such changing, I woulde Venus could make my wife a Man.

sp.speaker: Melleb.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Tyterus
sp.p: Because shee loues alwaies to play with men.

sp.speaker: Venus
sp.p: Well you are both fonde, therefore agree to thys changing, or suffer your Daughters to endure harde chaunce.

sp.speaker: Melleb.
sp.p: Howe say you Tyterus, shall wee referre it to Venus.

sp.speaker: Tyte.
sp.p: I am content, because she is a Goddesse.

sp.speaker: Venus
sp.p: Neptune you will not dislike it.

sp.speaker: Neptune
sp.p: Not I.

sp.speaker: Venus
sp.p: Nor you Diana.

sp.speaker: Diana
sp.p: Not I.

sp.speaker: Venus
sp.p: Cupid shall not.

sp.speaker: Cupid
sp.p: I will not.

sp.speaker: Venus
sp.p: Then let vs depart, neither of them shall know whose lot it shal be til they come to the Churchdore. One shall be, doth it suffise?

sp.speaker: Phillida
sp.p: And satis-fie vs both, dooth it not Gallathea?

sp.speaker: Galla.
sp.p: Yes Phillida.

sp.speaker: Rafe
sp.p: Come Robin, I am gladde I haue mette with thee, for nowe wee will make our Father laugh at these tales.

sp.speaker: Diana
sp.p: What are these that so malepartlie thrust themselues into our companies?

sp.speaker: Robin
sp.p: Forsooth Madame we are fortune tellers.

sp.speaker: Venus
sp.p: Fortune tellers; tell me my fortune.

sp.speaker: Rafe
sp.p: We doe not meane fortune tellers, we meane fortune tellers: we can tell what fortune wee haue had these twelue monthes in the Woods.

sp.speaker: Diana
sp.p: Let them alone, they be but peeuish.

sp.speaker: Venus
sp.p: Yet they will be as good as Minstrils at the marriage, to make vs all merrie.

sp.speaker: Dicke
sp.p: I Ladies we beare a very good Consort,

sp.speaker: Venus
sp.p: Can you sing?

sp.speaker: Rafe
sp.p: Baselie.

sp.speaker: Venus
sp.p: And you?

sp.speaker: Dicke
sp.p: Meanely.

sp.speaker: Venus
sp.p: And what can you doe?

sp.speaker: Robin
sp.p: If they duble it, I will treble it.

sp.speaker: Venus
sp.p: Then shall yee goe with vs, and sing Hymen before the marriage. Are you content?

sp.speaker: Rafe
sp.p: Content? neuer better content, for there we shall be sure to fill our bellies with Capons rumpes, or some such daintie dishes.

sp.speaker: Venus
sp.p: Then follow vs.

sp.speaker: Galla.
sp.p: GOE all, tis I onely that conclude al. You Ladies may see, that Venus can make constancie ficklenes, courage cowardice, modestie lightnesse, working things impossible in your Sexe, and tempering hardest harts like softest wooll. Yeelde Ladies, yeeld to loue Ladies, which lurketh vnder your eye-lids whilst you sleepe, and plaieth with your hart strings whilst you wake: whose sweetnes neuer breedeth satietie, labour wearinesse, nor greefe bitternesse. Cupid was begotten in a miste, nursed in Clowdes, and sucking onelie vpon conceits. Confesse him a Conquerer, whom yee ought to regarde, sith it is vnpossible to resist, for this is infallible, that Loue conquereth all things but it selfe, and Ladies all harts but their owne.
